resource.chars:
17. 
evidence had been sifted without bias and if due weight 
had been given to the opinions of the Members of the 
Expedition, it would have been found that our long vigil 
in the McMurdo Sound Region did not tend to prove the 
existence of an Antarctic Anticyclone, although a wider 
view of the Antarctic problem may possibly suggest its 
existence. 
I wish at this point to pay a tribute to the 
remarks contributed by Commander M.W.Campbell Hepworth 
(page 417 et seq). Not only are these remarks extremely 
instructive but it is evident that the author has taken 
the greatest pains to collect and correlate facts derived 
from many sources. 
Dr Chree in the interesting paper which follows 
deals only with accepted facts. 
Mr Dines in his 'Notes on Temperatures' (page 463) 
offers some remarks on the difficulties met with in 
reducing the low readings of the mercury thermometers to 
which I have referred in the early part of this letter. 
Apparently he did not attempt the reduction 
himself but accepted Dr Chree's corrections without 
question. He does not suggest that our procedure caused 
more than the slight addition to the work of reduction 
(which I have mentioned) but as he took no 
<u>share<\u>
